metadata.title: Proteomics based identification of differential plasma proteins and changes in white matter integrity as markers in early detection of mild cognitive impaired subjects at high risk of Alzheimers disease
metadata.abstract: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is an intermediate stage of cognitive decline and dementia. The absence of specific diagnostic test for identification of MCI and AD. The current study aims to find proteomics based change in plasma proteins and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) based white matter changes in MCI for early detection of prodromal Alzheimers disease. Fifty cases of mild cognitive impairment and age matched control between (55-75 yrs) were screened on basis of Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE). Two dimensional gel electrophoresis and DTI imaging was performed in MCI and age matched control. The MMSE score of MCI were in the range of (28  2-22.6  1) as compared with healthy control (28  2), DTI metrics apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) and fractional Anisotropy (FA) has shown significant changes in fornix, corpus callosum, hippocampus, right temporal and right frontal lobe, left frontal lobe, forcep major of MCI subjects as compared with controls. The protein expression of keratin type-2 was up regulated and albumin was down regulated in MCI subjects as compared with control. The data from present study signifies that expression of Keratin type-2 and albumin along with white matter changes provides early signatures for identification of MCI at high risk of Alzheimers disease

Introduction.text:
The mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is transitional stage between healthy ageing and very mild Alzheimers disease (AD). The main symptom of MCI is memory impairments that are out of proportion to that expected for their age. The conversion rate of MCI to AD dementia is 10-15 per year 1,2. The preliminary diagnosis of prodromal AD includes neurological examination, mental status test and brain imaging 3. The researches are ongoing to find specific biomarkers which may provide conclusive diagnosis of early AD. The challenges in development of biomarker for early detection of AD is its long asymptomatic prodromal stages, variability in clinical features, genetic polymorphism and molecular etiologies (e.g.) presenilin-1 (PS-1), presenilin-2 (PS-2) and APP mutation, apolipoprotein E (APOE) and sporadic AD 4. The blood is most non-invasive, less expensive and time saving source of biomarker entity, but due to selective nature of blood brain barrier, the brain protein do not exudates although diluted and over masked by highly abundant proteins present in blood 4.
Currently, amyloid beta protein, tau protein and phosphor-tau expression level are analyzed in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and act as valuable source of biomarkers, being in direct contact with brain and spinal cord it provides a complete representation of various biochemical and metabolic profile of brain, however, the invasive procedure of CSF isolation and irreproducible results, has limited these biomarkers to be used in diagnosis of early AD 5,6. Neuroimaging is used as prospective area for enhancement of early detection of cognitive impairment before the progression to clinical AD 789. The microscopic changes in white matter of AD was reported by Brun and Englund, these author reported that there was change in myelin sheath, axon and oligodendroglial cell with mild glial reactions 10. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) has provided significant evidences that white matter integrity is altered in cognitive normal individuals at high risk of AD and decreased significantly in AD 11,12. The report of DTI imaging in normal individual at high risk of AD have shown white matter changes in parahippocampal white matter, caudal portion of cingulum, fornix and posterior portion of corpus callosum 131415. Studies have shown that DTI can contribute in identification of white matter changes in age related cognitive decline 11,16. Although, blood samples are easy to obtain and exploration of biomarker in serumplasma become essentially significant. The recent study conduced by Blasko and coworkers revealed that Aβ-42 level were high in MCI and drops as cognitive function of patient decline in AD 17. Therefore, the current study was undertaken to find change in plasma protein profile of MCI and changes in white matter integrity as compared with age match healthy control to find early marker for detection of prodromal stage of Alzheimers dementia.

Materials.text: Bovine serum albumin (BSA), Tris-base, acrylamide, N, N methylene bisacrylamide, urea, agarose, 3-(3-cholamidopropyl) dimethylammonio-1-propanesulfonate (CHAPS), sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS), dithioerythreitol (DTE), dithiothreitol (DTT), bromophenol blue, Tween-20, ethylene-diamine-tetra-acetic acid (EDTA), protease inhibitor cocktail were purchased from Merck, India. Bradford reagent was procured from Bio-Rad, USA and Immobiline pH gradient strips, Immobiline pH gradient buffer and cover fluid were purchased from Bio-Rad, USA. Glycerol, sodium thiosulfate, potassium ferricyanide, silver nitrate, PVDF sodium carbonate, formaldehyde, methanol were procured from Merck Limited, India. Thiourea, acetonitrile, acetic acid, ammonium bicarbonate, triflouroacetic acid (TFA) and other chemicals required for the study were procured locally from Merck, India.

Sample collection.text: The study was a prospective case control study performed after ethical consent of Institutional Medical Ethics Committee of Sir Sundar lal hospital, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India. The study was conducted from June 2015 to September 2017. The informed ethical consent form approved by institutional ethical committee was filled for each individual registered for the study and after their written consent, the study was conducted. Cases were elderly individual between age group of 55-75 years of either gender, selected on the basis of following inclusion criteria HindiEnglish speaking, age  50 years old, memory complaint for more than six month, stable and controlled medical conditions such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia, exclusion criteria: Subjects having neurological diseases including stroke, severe small vessel disease and any other systemic problem. All cases were subjected to routine clinical interview and completed neuropsychological tests at baseline and follow-up at our outpatient clinic. MCI was diagnosed according to criteria of Petersen and coworker 1. Further, all MCI subjects had complaint of subjective memory over last six month and had Clinical Dementia Rating Scale CDR sore of 0.5, and impaired memory function verbal or figural in neuropsychological assessment -1.5 standard deviation SD related to age and education. Healthy elderly age matched controls that did not meet the criteria for dementia and presented no cognitive complaints or performance below -1.5 SD on neuropsychological test.

Routine morphologicalanatomical MRI.text: The routine MRI of healthy elderly and MCI subjects were performed on MRI 1.5 T Magnetom Avanto Version BV-I7A; Siemens Medical System, Erlangen, Germany system, equipped with an actively shielded whole body magnet. A quadrature bird-cage transmit receive coil 8 channel was used for imaging.

Diffusion tensor imaging.text: The DTI sequence utilized was a single-shot, balanced echoplannar imaging EPI sequence with timing parameters of TR 6000 ms and TE 97 ms. Twenty contiguous transverse slices with a slice thickness of 5 mm were aligned parallel to the anterior commissure and posterior commissure plane and covered all but the topmost part of the brain. The FOV was 128  128 mm, acquisition matrix 96  128, reconstructed to 128  128, giving a reconstructed in-plane resolution of 1.78 mm  1.78 mm. For each slice, one image without diffusion weighting b  0 smm2 and six images with diffusion weighting b0  1000 smm2 applied along six non-collinear directions were acquired. The six DTI acquisitions for each subject were registered using a mutual information cost function and a 12-parameter transformation with the first b  0 smm2 volume reference.

Post-processing and analysis.text: Data post-processing was done using the automated Neuro-3D software Siemens Medical System on the offline workstation. The image analysis was performed in presence of expert Neurologist and Radiologist. The senior Radiologist, however, evaluated and reported the DTI data prior to viewing the routine MR imaging, to exclude any kind of observer bias. Another senior Radiologist, with twenty five years experience, evaluated all the sequences to ascertain the quality of imaging and validity of data collection.

Estimation of protein content.text: Protein concentration was measured by Bradfords method 18 using bovine serum albumin (BSA) as standard.

Two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel elect.text: 2D-PAGE was performed using standard procedure 19,20. The rehydration reaction was done by using equal amount of protein of controls and MCI subjects, about (200mg) along with 150 ml commercial isoelectric focusing rehydration buffer containing 8 M urea, 2 CHAPS, 0.5 IPG buffer, 0.02 bromophenol blue and 15 mM DTT along with IPG strip (pH 4-7) was performed overnight at room temperature and isoelectric focusing was performed in a Multiphor II electrophoresis unit (Bio Rad) for 14, 000 V h. Second dimension electrophoresis was performed using 12.5 resolving polyacrylamide gel. The resultant gels were stained with silver nitrate using standard procedure 21.

2D-gel analysis.text: The 2D gels of control and MCI subjects were compared using Image Master 2D platinum software. The contrast for background and spots were normalized in every gel. Each gel was assigned landmark, following spot matching, normalized volume of spots from individual gels was compared between groups to calculate change in volume in MCI versus control. The change in volume of spots in 2D gels of controls and MCI subjects was calculated and 2D spots with significant change in spot volume was used for further analysis.

Sample preparation for mass spectrometry.text: The sample for mass spectrometry was made using standard procedure 22 with slight modifications. To remove silver stains excised spots were incubated with 250 μl of 50 mM sodium thiosulfate and 15 mM potassium ferricyanide for 5 min and washed twice with 500 μl water to remove reducing agents. Sliced spots were rehydrated in 30 μl of a solution containing 0.02 μgμl trypsin and 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate at 4 C for 60 min. The supernatant was discarded and 30-50 μl of 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate was added in excised spots, incubated at 37 C for 16-18 h and supernatant was taken. In the pellet, 25-50 μl of 1 TFA in 60 acetonitrile was added and sonicated for 10 min. The supernatant was taken following centrifugation at 12,000xg for 30 s. Both the supernatant were mixed, freeze-dried and concentrated by centrifugal evaporation to dryness. Mass spectrometric analysis of samples was done at Interdisciplinary School of Life Sciences, Institute of Science, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi. In brief, matrix, namely a-cyano-4-hydroxy cinnamic acid (CHCA) matrix, was mixed with the dissolved trypsinized peptide samples. After drying, the peptides were spotted on ground steel plate and subjected to Bruker Ultraflex MALDI-TOFTOF and MS MS for mass spectrometric identification. The instrument was equipped with a pulsed nitrogen laser.

Analysis of peptide sequence.text: Data acquisition and analysis was performed using flex control and flex analysisbiotools version 2.2 software, respectively. Data were acquired in reflectron positive mode using 15-18 laser power. The MALDI and tandem spectra used for protein identification from tryptic fragments were searched against MASCOT search engine. Probability based MOWSE score was calculated in terms of ion score -10Log (P), where P is the probability and observed match was considered as a random event.

Western blotting.text: The expression of Keratin type 2 protein in serum of MCI subject was significantly increased as compared with control (p  0.001) Fig. 2A B. Albumin expression was significantly down regulated as compared with control (p  0.01) Fig. 2A C. Keratin type 2 expression in cerebrospinal fluid of MCI subject was significantly higher as compared with controls and dementia with lewy body (DLB) group (p  0.001) Fig. 2D  E.

Statistical analysis.text: The comparison between control and MCI group was done using Mann-Whitney test and One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used for comparisons between control, MCI and dementia with lewy body (DLB) group, with the Newman Keuls post-hoc test. The correlation between two variables in MCI subjects were determined by Spearman correlation coefficient. The p-value 0.05 was considered to be practical level of clinical significance.

Neuropsychological and demographic data.text: The screening of elderly population by Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) revealed that 50 individuals with age group from (55-75 years) and MMSE score (28  2-22.6  1) were cognitive decline as compared with age matched healthy controls with MMSE score of (28  2). The details of education years and demographic location of MCI and controls subject are given in (Table 1).

Diffusion tensor imaging analysis.text: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) based Fractional Anisotropy (FA) and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) was assessed in 22 regions of interest ROI with 44 variables. The FA values of right and left frontal lobe, fornix, and forcep major, corpus callosum showed significant decline as compared with controls. The ADC values of right temporal lobe, hippocampus head, and forcep major, corpus callosum have higher ADC value as compared with control (Table 2).

Two dimensional (2D) gel electrophoresis.text: The plasma protein of control and MCI were subjected to 2D gel electrophoresis and each set of experiment were repeated twice. The data was analyzed by Image master 2D platinum Software (G.E. Health Care, USA). The complete 2D gel profile of resolved proteins of control and MCI subjects were shown in Fig. 1. The volume changes of spots among the groups greater than 2 fold as compared with control were taken under consideration. The expression of two proteins was found to be differentially regulated in plasma of MCI subject as compared with control, the protein spot 2 was up-regulated more than two fold, while protein spot 1 was down regulated as compared with control (Fig. 1A). Mass spectrometric analysis using MALDI-TOF and MS-MS identified these proteins as Keratin type II which was up regulated significantly in MCI as compared with control (p  0.01) and albumin was down regulated in MCI subjects as compared with control (p  0.05) Fig. 1B.

Correlation of keratin type 2 protein ex.text: The value of Spearman correlation coefficient calculated between

Discussion.text: The MCI subjects reported in our studies have shown significant decline in cognitive function as evaluated by Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) neuropsychological test. The decrease in FA value in right and left frontal lobe, fornix, forcep major, corpus callosum and increase in ADC value of right temporal lobe, hippocampus head, corpus callosum and forcep major decreases neuropsychological function such as orientation, immediate recall, attention, 3-step command, delayed recall, naming, reading and comprehension, copy design in MCI subjects as compared with control. The expression of keratin type 2 protein was negative correlated with MMSE score in our study, which depicts lower MMSE score and higher expression of keratin type 2 in MCI subjects. Further, ADC and FA values was strongly correlated with the expression of keratin type 2 in MCI subjects, which implicate that white matter changes and increase in keratin type 2 expression are involved in neurodegeneration. The changes in cognitive functions in MCI subject in our study is in agreement with previous study of Stricker and coworker, in which they depicted that decrease in white matter integrity, was related to cognition and is independent of cortical thinning 23. The identification of keratin type 2 and albumin precursor protein in our study implicates its role in AD pathology, although reports are available in which keratin 9 and albumin were important component of biomarker panel for diagnosing AD 24. The proteomics of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica patient found that expression of keratin was two fold higher as compared with control 25. Recent, studies by Lie and coworker identified keratin as one of the potential molecule involved in AD pathology but its action of mechanism is still unknown 26. The increase in expression of keratin type 2 in MCI subject in our study indicates that white matter degeneration due to ageing result in myelin sheath to disintegrate which mainly composed of proteolipid having keratin as major constituent, these keratin might exudates from blood brain barrier into the peripheral system. The higher concentration of proteolipid in white matter as compared with grey matter is already reported 27. To ascertain that increase keratin type 2 level in plasma might not be due to entry of keratinocytes through punctured skin in blood plasma, we also checked the level of keratin type 2 in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of MCI subjects and subject having dementia with lewy bodies (DLB), the concentration of keratin type 2 was significantly higher as compared with control and DLB. Further, Keratin 9 was found linked to Wnt-signaling cascade via interaction with adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) and Cadherin 1 (CDH1), which might be involved in signaling of keratinocytes development 28. The dysfunction of blood brain barrier (BBB) has been implicated in AD, and its maintenance through tight junction protein is regulated by Wnt-signaling pathway 28. The activation of Dickkopf (DKK1), which is wntpathway antagonist, induces keratin expression in epidermis, furthermore its expression was found higher in brain of AD patient 29,30. The neurodegeneration in MCI subject as evident from white matter changes, in our study strongly correlates with increase in DKK1 expression which might induce the Keratin level in plasma through BBB dysfunction. Although, the expression of DKK1 need to be validated in MCI subject, but due to non-availability of tissue sample it could not be done. The expression of albumin was significantly lower in MCI subject as compared with control. The decrease in albumin level in our study is in agreement with previous case control studies, which linked low level of albumin with cognitive impairment 31,32. The role of inflammatory mediators and free radical in pathogenesis of MCI and dementia is widely accepted 33. The free radical generation in MCI subjects causes cell death, by damaging lipids, DNA, protein and carbohydrates, while the reaction between neurotransmitter and free radical form neurotoxin leads to neurodegeneration 34. The albumin act as plasma oxygen trapping and antioxidant defense for both endogenous and exogenous free radicals 35,36. The plasma albumin play vital role in conjugation with drugs, hormones and free fatty acid, the lower level of albumin might lead to neurotoxicty which results in mild cognitive impairment. Albumin also inhibits the formation of amyloid beta-peptide fibrils 37. The lower level of albumin in plasma and CSF might induce Alzheimers type pathology as reported earlier 38. The data from current study indicate that white matter changes and up regulation of Keratin and down regulation of albumin in plasma of MCI subjects might provide initial signatures for identification of MCI at prodromal stage.

Conclusion.text: The data from present study highlights that Mini Mental State Examination neuropsychological test and diffusion tensor imaging based white matter changes in mild cognitive impaired subjects are highly correlated and can be used for primary screening of elderly population suffering from cognitive decline. Further, down regulation of plasma albumin and up regulation of Keratin type 2 protein in plasma of MCI subject as compared with control, will provide specific marker for identification of MCI subjects at high risk for developing Alzheimers disease.
